title: World Series Game 6 interference call among most controversial in MLB postseason history
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Joe Torre addressed the media after Game 6 of the World Series in an effort to try and explain what Trae Turner did wrong to insight the controversial call. USA TODAY

In the aftermath of the Washington Nationals’ Game 6 victory over the Houston Astros on Tuesday, all conversations are prefaced with the seventh-inning call that set the baseball world — and Nats manager Dave Martinez — on fire.

Trea Turner was running to first base when reliever Brad Peacock’s throw got to the bag the same time Turner did, and he made it to second with Yan Gomes standing on third following the play. But home plate umpire Sam Holbrook ruled Turner out for interference and Gomes returned to first. Had Anthony Rendon not homered two batters later to increase Washington's lead to 5-2, the call could have had more serious ramifications.

Of course, controversial calls in the MLB postseason are nothing new. From fan interference to obstruction, playoff umpires have seen it all over the years.

Let’s take a look at the most controversial plays over the past 35 years in postseason history.

Fan interference call on Jose Altuve's 'homer'

In the first inning of last year's ALCS Game 4 between the Boston Red Sox and Houston Astros, a fan interference call prevented a potential game-tying, two-run home run for Jose Altuve.

As Red Sox right fielder Mookie Betts went back to the right field wall and reached for the ball, a frenzy of fans in the front row did the same. In doing so, the fans made contact with Betts’ glove, preventing him from making the catch. Umpire Joe West called Altuve out on fan interference.

In a game that ended in an 8-6 Red Sox victory, the impact of the call was impossible to ignore.

Chase Utley’s slide upends Ruben Tejada

In the bottom of the seventh of Game 2 of the NLDS in 2015, the New York Mets were trying to preserve their 2-1 lead with a pair of Los Angeles Dodgers on the bases and one out.

Pitcher Bartolo Colon hit a ball to Daniel Murphy just to the right of second base. Murphy flipped the ball to shortstop Ruben Tejada, who stepped on second and turned to get the inning-ending out at first. That’s when Chase Utley, running from first base on the play, slid directly into Tejada, upending him and ending all chances of a double play. Utley was called safe after a review, when it was determined that Tejada never touched the bag.

Ump calls infield fly rule on Andrelton Simmons

With one out and two runners on in the bottom of the eighth inning, the Atlanta Braves were threatening to chip away at the St. Louis Cardinals’ 6-3 lead in the 2012 NL Wild Card Game.

Braves shortstop Andrelton Simmons hit a high pop up to left field that fell in between Cardinals fielders Pete Kozma and Matt Holliday. As a result, the bases were loaded. That is until left field umpire Sam Holbrook ruled that Simmons was out on account of an infield fly. The MLB rulebook cites that an infield fly is in play if the ball could “ordinarily have been handled by an infielder — not by some arbitrary limitation such as the grass, or the base lines.” However, the ball seemingly dropped closer to where the left fielder Holliday was originally positioned, not the shortstop Kozma.

Despite the ball traveling well into left field, Simmons was called out on an infield fly, cutting the Braves’ rally short. The Cardinals went on to win, 6-3.

Cardinals win on a walk-off obstruction call

The St. Louis Cardinals were tied 4-4 with the Red Sox in the bottom of the ninth of Game 3 of the 2013 World Series. St. Louis had runners on second and third with one out and a chance to take a series lead with a win. They got the walk-off they were looking for, just not in the fashion they might have expected.

Allen Craig was ruled safe on an obstruction call against Red Sox third baseman Will Middlebrooks, who tripped Craig as he darted for home on a ball that sailed past third base. Umpire Jim Joyce called obstruction and Craig scored the game-winning run, despite never actually touching home plate.

The play marked the only time a postseason game has ever ended on an obstruction call.

Matt Holliday slides, misses home plate

Matt Holliday’s slide into home in the 13th inning of a tiebreaking playoff in 2007 remains memorable.

With closer Trevor Hoffman on the mound and an 8-6 lead, the Padres were three outs away from a spot in the NLDS.

The Rockies tied the game on RBI hits from Kazuo Matsui and Holliday, when Jamey Carroll came to the plate with a chance to win the game.

Carroll shot a liner into the glove of Padres right fielder Brian Giles, who made an impressive throw to home. Holliday slid, driving his hand into the foot of the Padres catcher. He was called safe by home plate umpire Tim McClelland, but it was unclear as to whether Holliday actually touched the bag.

To this day, there is no clear-cut evidence of Holliday actually touching the bag, so McClelland’s word still stands. With the modern influence of replay review and better camera quality, one has to wonder how this play would have unfolded if it took place a decade later.

The Steve Bartman play

The Steve Bartman play in Game 6 of the 2003 NLCS lives on in baseball lore because of a no-call on fan interference, partially leading to the Chicago Cubs’ blowing a late-inning lead and eventually the series.

Florida Marlins second baseman Luis Castillo sent a fly ball into foul territory along the left field line. Cubs left fielder Moises Alou made his way to the wall in time to make a play on the ball, when Bartman intercepted the ball before Alou could potentially make the catch.

Cubs shortstop Alex Gonzalez botched a potential inning-ending double play just moments later, and the Marlins poured on eight runs in the inning to go on to win the game as well as the series.

Many in the stadium, including a demonstrative Alou, clamored for fan interference, which would have called Castillo out.

Jeffrey Maier helps Derek Jeter’s home run

Jeffrey Maier became one of the most famous fans in baseball history when was on the receiving end of Derek Jeter’s controversial home run in Game 1 of the 1996 ALCS.

As supported by multiple replay review angles, Maier reached over the right-field wall to haul in Jeter’s fly ball, preventing Baltimore Orioles right fielder Tony Tarasco from making the catch below. Tarasco was directly under the ball and appeared to be right in line to make the catch, but Maier caught it first and the Yankees went on to win in extra innings, 5-4.

Umpire Don Denkinger’s blown call

There is little controversy about this one; Jorge Orta was out at first.

The Cardinals were clinging to a 1-0 lead heading into the ninth inning of Game 6 of the 1985 Word Series when the Kansas City Royals’ Orta hit a slow grounder to the right side of the infield. First baseman Jack Clark fielded it and tossed it to relief pitcher Todd Worrell, who was covering first. Replays showed that Orta got to the bag after the ball got to Worrell, but first base umpire Don Denkinger called him safe.

Orta was pulled for pinch runner Onix Concepcion, who scored the game-tying run as the Royals went on to win the game and later the series.

Contributing: Chris Bumbaca
description: Baseball is a game of intricacies and subjectivity. That doesn't change in the playoffs. Here are some of the more controversial postseason calls.
